wikipedia_page.main: Elizabeth Josephine Craig, MBE, FRSA (16 February 1883 – 7 June 1980) was a Scottish journalist, home economist and a notable author on cookery.

response: *1980 – Elizabeth Craig, Scottish journalist and economist (b. 1883)
**Elizabeth Craig, 97, Scottish author of bestselling cookbooks from 1918 to 1980.

The village's most famous resident was the actress Deborah Kerr, who died there on 16 October 2007. Another notable resident was the artist and theatrical designer Audrey Cruddas, who lived at Bank House during the 1960s and '70s. Elizabeth Craig, the cookery writer, lived in St Catherine's, one of the oldest houses in the village, from the 1960s onwards, and wrote an article, 'Footsteps in the Grass', in East Anglia Monthly, documenting the house's history. Newman Knowlys, the Recorder of London in the early 19th century, was educated in the village.

Henry is the son of Brian Henry, well-known figure in independent TV in London and great-nephew of Elizabeth Craig MBE Scottish journalist, cook  and author. She appeared on the 'over 90s' show on BBC TV Parkinson in 1978 aged 95 alongside Rt Honourable Manny Shinwell MP and the playwright Ben Travers CBE.
* Elizabeth Craig (writer) (1883–1980), Scottish journalist, home economist and cookery writer
* Elizabeth Craig (politician) (born 1967/68), New Zealand politician and physician
